prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CS as a high-density tracer
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: In this Sience Goal we will observe CS (a high-density tracer) , SiC, CN and 29SiC2. The hyperfine structure of CN transitions provide independent optical depth measurements and hence can be used for an accurate estimate of the column density.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral Resolution: The 226GHz SMA observations have a 0.8 MHz = 0.8km/s wide channels (see Fig. \ref{emission}). Using ALMA band 6 with the BLcor, dual polarisation with 937.5 MHz bandwidth we will achieve an effective velocity resolution of $\sim$0.5 km/s. As the typical FWHM for the narrowest line in NGC 6302 is $\sim$5km/s this will be sufficient to detect the weakest line.
Sensitivity and Observing time: In our first science goal with a representative frequency of 226.5GHz, we aim for an rms of 0.04K per a smoothed 1 km/s channel. Assuming 34 (12m) antennas, dual polarisation and velocity resolution of 1 km/s, for band 6, the ALMA sensitivity calculator for these sources predicts a ToS of 6.31 minutes, giving a total (10 sources, calibratos and overheads) of 2.25h
We are aware that the data rate we are asking is higher than the stated for ALMA as a limit. But because our weakest lines are in the order of 3km/s we need at least 0.5km/s resoltuion for us to detect it, and then we can smoothed it out to 1km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN: looking for outflows
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: For this Sience Goal we will observe HCO+ and HCN thus providing information on both outflows and the PDR interface, whilst simultaneously observing SiO, SO2 and SiS which will establish the longevity of these molecules in the torii.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
For the second science goal, similarily to the first science goal, we aim for an rms of 0.04K but with a representative frequency of 265.88619GHz. With a 937.5 MHz bandwidth and hence a smoothed $\sim$1 km/s velocity resolution, the ALMA sensitivity calculator for these sources predicts a ToS of 6.57 minutes, giving a total (10 sources, calibratos and overheads) of 2.30h.
We are aware that the data rate we are asking is higher than the stated for ALMA as a limit. But because our weakest lines are in the order of 3km/s we need at least 0.5km/s resoltuion for us to detect it, and then we can smoothed it out to 1km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2O and 13CO constraining the models
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of 13CO and H$_2$O are also very important. Therefore we will observe it in our third goal. It will help to constrain the chemical networks involved in explaining HCO+ abundances, as well as providing a useful diagnostic tool to investigate the HI/H2 transition layer in PDRs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
For the third science goal, we aim for a similar rms of 0.04K but with a representative frequency of 235.78GHz. With a 937.5 MHz bandwidth and a smoothed $\sim$1 km/s velocity resolution, the ALMA sensitivity calculator for these sources predicts a ToS of 8.14 minutes, giving a total (10 sources, calibratos and overheads) of 2.68h.
We are aware that the data rate we are asking is higher than the stated for ALMA as a limit. But because our weakest lines are in the order of 3km/s we need at least 0.5km/s resoltuion for us to detect it, and then we can smoothed it out to 1km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Planetary nebulae (PNe) represent the last stage of evolution of intermediate mass stars (0.8 to 8 M$_{\odot}$) and hence are fundamental to galactic evolution. The massive envelopes ejected during their earlier evolution (AGB phase) are an important source of recycled material in the form of dust and molecular gas into the interstellar medium. Although their ionised nebulae have been observed and studied for more than two centuries at optical frequencies, their molecular counterpart in the millimetre and submillimetre has only recently been investigated (for example Bachiller et al, 1997)\nocite{Bachiller97}. Consequently, the understanding of many of the late evolutionary processes involved in the transition of low and intermediate-mass stars from the proto-planetary (PPN) and onto the PN phase still remain largely unknown.
